55.text:
Let us now consider the structure of the qualification.
GCSE Business Studies is made up of three

69.text:
units. Units 1 and 2 are compulsory and together
are worth 50% of the full GCSE. Centres then

78.text:
have the option of choosing which pathway
candidates follow through either Unit 3, 4

84.text:
or 5. Details are on the screen.
The focus of this session is Unit 2 - controlled

97.text:
assessment. This, like Unit 1, is worth 25%
of the qualification. Note that Unit 2 is

105.text:
based on the specification content of Unit
1 - 'Introduction to Small Business'.

110.text:
In this session we will look at the assessment
criteria for Unit 2 to help you have a clear

118.text:
understanding of how the unit is assessed
and to facilitate work carried out in schools

123.text:
and colleges.
The following information will be particularly

133.text:
useful for teachers and centres that have
not previously delivered Edexcel GCSE Business

138.text:
Studies. It will still serve as a refresher
for existing teachers and centres.

144.text:
Importantly, candidates have a choice of 5
investigation tasks. These are drawn from

152.text:
the 5 topics in the Unit 1 specification.
Best practice from previous series - and the

159.text:
spirit of this qualification - is that candidates
are allowed to choose one of the 5 tasks,

164.text:
rather than the centre deciding that all candidates
will do the same task. Also, it is recommended

172.text:
that candidates should each investigate a
different business. Evidence suggests that,

178.text:
in choosing a business, candidates have greater
ownership of their investigation.

183.text:
There are 4 assessment criteria - Research,
Presentation, Analysis and Evaluation. These

194.text:
will be considered in more detail shortly.
Before then, some technical information that

200.text:
centres need to be aware of.
The investigation is to be carried out under

210.text:
controlled conditions. Research should be
up to 6 hours under low levels of control.

218.text:
This can be done in the classroom and for
homework.

221.text:
The write-up is 3 hours and under conditions
of high control.

227.text:
In terms of the timing of controlled assessment,
the information on this slide provides a summary

238.text:
of key dates. Delegates are advised to pause
the slideshow at this point to ensure they

246.text:
The last point is based on advice from previous
series. Whilst it is not permitted to allow

255.text:
candidates to practice controlled assessment
using the current series, it is good practice

260.text:
to provide an opportunity for candidates to
carry out a practice investigation - a 'dummy

265.text:
run' - based on tasks from a previous series.
This will allow candidates to understand the

272.text:
assessment criteria and to experience the
time constraints and other challenges that

278.text:
the real thing will present. This is not compulsory,
however. Centres have some freedom over when

286.text:
they do the controlled assessment. This can
be either in Year 10, or Autumn or Spring

292.text:
of Year 11.
Other points to note are shown on this slide.

302.text:
Note that, during the final write-up, no internet
access is permitted. By this stage - that

310.text:
is, after the 6 hours of research - candidates
should have their research (in electronic

316.text:
or hard copy), and will use this as part of
their write-up.

326.text:
A note on drafting. The information on this

Assessment Regulations document.
And so to the assessment criteria. It is recommended

345.text:
at this point that delegates pause the recording
and have this document to hand. This is what

352.text:
will be used to mark controlled assessment
by centres and moderators. Candidates should

357.text:
be comfortable with these criteria, and what
constitutes performance in different bands.

367.text:
Note that 'Knowledge' is not one of the criteria.
The weighting of Unit 2 is based around AO2

375.text:
and AO3. AO1 which includes Knowledge is the
key element of the Unit 1 assessment.

388.text:
And so to Research. 12 marks are available
for Research. It is important to be clear

395.text:
that there is no simple numerical formula
equating a number of pieces of research with

400.text:
a number of marks. What is important is that
research that is collected is relevant to

408.text:
the specific tasks. 'Selectivity and focus'
are key. Encourage students to ask the question:

416.text:
Does this research help me to answer my investigation
question?.

421.text:
As there are no marks for Knowledge in controlled
assessment, so candidates should not spend

427.text:
time researching and presenting information
on theory.

430.text:
Candidates should be encouraged to think about
the type of research that is appropriate for

435.text:
their chosen title. This might involve primary
and secondary research. Note that in each

444.text:
series there will be one task of the five
that can be completed using only secondary

450.text:
research.
Consider this example of an investigation.

461.text:
The candidate has chosen a small business
to investigate to ascertain the 'most important

467.text:
factor in helping this business deliver high
levels of customer satisfaction'. The work,

473.text:
at first glance, is well-presented and neatly
laid out. (We will look in more detail at

479.text:
the Presentation criterion shortly). They
have also carried out some potentially useful

486.text:
Research by taking photographs of the inside
of the business. Images could be useful in

494.text:
working out how the business delivers customer
satisfaction. Promising.

499.text:
However, further consideration shows that
the only reference made to this research is

506.text:
the statement: Below is an image of the centre
of the shop. This is not really Research that

512.text:
is being used to help answer the question
in the title.

517.text:
We will consider Analysis later, but what
this candidate does not do is make use of

523.text:
the research they have carried out. In this
sense the Research images are working as 'decoration'

531.text:
and are not being used to help answer the
question. We will consider this later when

536.text:
we look at Analysis.
Some advice on the area of Research is shown

548.text:
It is strongly recommended that candidates
organise their research file into a series

552.text:
of appendices that are attached to their work
and are submitted by the centre when work

557.text:
is called for moderation.
Presentation is worth 8 marks. Key here is

569.text:
the reference to 'attention to detail'. Some
suggestions are included here.

576.text:
Note that it is perfectly fine for candidates
to write their investigation by hand and with

582.text:
no detriment to their Presentation mark. The
same emphasis on 'attention to detail' applies.

595.text:
Analysis is worth 12 marks. It is very important
that candidates use their research evidence

602.text:
to help them answer their investigation title.
The need here is for original thinking based

609.text:
on the research. Importantly, no credit is
given for the analysis of different theories

616.text:
Analysis involves identifying reasons, consequences,
causes, issues or factors.

624.text:
Looking at the descriptor for the 7'9 band,
Analysis should be, 'detailed and relevant',

637.text:
and 'shows clear understanding'.
Revisiting the example from earlier in this

648.text:
presentation, the Research image the candidate
had gathered is reproduced here.

654.text:
What could the candidate have done with this
source to help them answer the question and

659.text: to demonstrate the skills of Analysis.

663.text:
Some suggestions are shown. There is certainly
evidence from this image that the business

669.text:
does quite a lot to deliver customer satisfaction,
from the organisation of the paints and the

675.text:
outward-facing handles, to the clear aisles
and the organisation of products into certain

680.text:
areas. There are lots of opportunities to
actually analyse this research evidence. This

687.text:
candidate did not do this at all, and missed
a real opportunity. In fact, for this part

694.text:
of their work they scored 0 for Analysis,
whereas with some thinking, they could have

700.text:
demonstrated higher level Analysis on this
source alone.

710.text:
Evaluation is worth 8 marks. This is typically
the weakest area of candidate performance

715.text:
in each series. To demonstrate Evaluation
candidates need to make direct use of their

722.text:
Research and Analysis to arrive at a reasoned
answer to the investigation question. This

728.text:
must be drawn from the Analysis that has been
carried out.

731.text:
Typically, investigations will require candidates
to consider the most important factor from

743.text:
a range of factors. For example, in the 2015
tasks, Task 4 invited candidates to identify

753.text:
how a business might improve how it motivates
its staff.

758.text:
Pause the recording to consider the type of
research and analysis a candidate could carry

763.text:
out for this task, and what the Evaluation
might actually look like. Pause now.

775.text:
This is the type of tasks that can be carried
out in class with students. There are lots

780.text:
of opportunities for Research with this task.
Candidates should find out what the current

786.text:
methods of motivation are. Bear in mind that
the focus is on small businesses, so candidates

793.text:
should not expect to see lots of traditional
'textbook' methods, such as company cars,

798.text: private health insurance and so on.

801.text:
Candidates could find out this information
by primary research within the business, for

807.text:
example by interviewing the owner, or asking
employees to conduct a simple questionnaire.

813.text:
The results of this research can be analysed
to ascertain what the current methods if any

821.text:
Evaluation can take place when research data
and analysis are in place. Evaluation is a

829.text:
higher order skill, and this is one reason
why candidates find it difficult. Conclusions

836.text:
should be based on the research and should
offer original insights.

847.text:
A note of caution on Evaluation. No reward
should be given to candidates for evaluating

853.text:
their process or approach. Pause the recording
to look at the three examples on screen from

860.text:
the 2015 series. In all cases the candidates
comment on the process. Note also, especially

870.text:
on the third example, how the annotation by
the teacher seems to suggest that this is

875.text:
being rewarded. None of the examples here
have any merit in terms of Evaluation.

883.text:
This is a simple message that delegates can
pass onto their own students.

Read the script and give it a mark for Research,
Presentation, Analysis and Evaluation.

918.text:
This is a sound piece of work. The candidate
has clearly investigated the small business,

925.text:
C&M Development Ltd. The owner was interviewed
and employees were surveyed. Work is presented

933.text:
effectively using a range of techniques. Different
methods to improve motivation are suggested

939.text:
and these are relevant and appropriate.
The marks awarded are as follows:

944.text:
Research 9 marks. A good range of sources
is used by the candidate, and these are focussed

951.text:
on the specific tasks.
Presentation 6 marks.

956.text:
Analysis 7 marks. There is some analysis of
the research data, although this is at times

963.text:
a little superficial. This was judged to be
slightly better than 'simple analysis', and

969.text:
was just placed into the 7-9 band.
Evaluation 5 marks. A conclusion is arrived

979.text:
at and this is based on the research and analysis
that has taken place. A ranking activity is

986.text:
carried out, although this is a little superficial.
This is worthy of the 5-6 band.

993.text:
This work was awarded 27 out of 40. This mark
was equivalent to a C grade, based on the

1001.text:
2015 grade boundaries.
